page.title: 04Wildlife of the Lune-Melling
page.content: On the shingle banks of the R.Lune nest many oyster catchers. Lapwings are plentiful along the river. They used to live in the fields but have moved on to the gravel beds of the river. There are many common sand pipers and some curlew along the river bank and in our part there is a Kingfisher. This year we went to look at a pair of mute swans nesting. Last week we saw them on a backwater with one cygnet. There was a pair of roe deer last year by the railway viaduct. They had two young deer but these twins were killed on the railway bridge. We aren't sure whether the adults are still there. Twice a year, mainly during the night, our sleep is sometimes disturbed by strange sounds passing overhead, down and up the valley. They are flocks of geese migrating in formation.
